So my recommendation is break fulfillment into two parts. Okay? You have communication on the one hand, then you have delivery on the other. So for communication, keep it really simple. And very few consultants actually do this, which is unfortunate, or maybe it's fortunate for us, cuz if you did great work and your client is really happy, then they even go as far as thanking you for that work. title: How I Would Start AI Consulting in 2026 (If I could start over)
author: Nick Saraev

key_facts: The speaker has scaled multiple agencies to $160,000 per month in combined revenue.
The speaker has spent hundreds of thousands of dollars on mapping out the optimal path for an AI consulting agency.
The five pillars of an AI consulting agency are marketing, sales, onboarding, fulfillment, and retention.
Upwork is cited as a platform where the speaker earned over $500,000 directly.
Cold email can scale independently of time investment, allowing 2,000 emails to be sent daily with the same system.
A client in Maker School closed almost $15,000 in one month using LinkedIn outreach.
The speaker uses a 30-45 minute sales structure with six stages: rapport, schedule setting, discovery, solution proposal, investment framing, and proposal sending.
Onboarding includes a kickoff call covering introductions, goals and timelines, communication expectations, and platform access.
Platform access and two-factor authentication are handled live during the kickoff call to avoid delays.
Daily check-ins are sent Monday through Friday via Slack, email, or WhatsApp to maintain client trust.
Delivery involves packaging systems like products, including Loom video walkthroughs and documentation.
Overdelivering by 5% triggers reciprocity and increases the likelihood of follow-up project sales.
The speaker offers free templates, scripts, and workflows for all five pillars.
The speakers Gumroad library contains automations sold for between $2,000 and $15,000.
Maker School has over 2,500 members learning and building AI consulting businesses.
key_opinions: Marketing is the only thing that matters for a business at $0 revenue.
Cold email is a money printer due to its high leverage and scalability.
Communities require consistency and are a grind but build long-term authority.
Cold DMs are effective only when messages appear hyperpersonalized and informal.
Sales should not begin with pricing; value must be built first.
Clients prefer logical and emotional decisions over impulsive ones.
Handling objections requires going deeper rather than accepting vague responses.
Sending proposals instead of closing on calls leads to better client alignment.
Managing perception of service delivery is more important than the actual work.
Retention is often overlooked but represents significant untapped revenue potential.
Overdelivering slightly increases client trust and opens doors for future projects.
The best time to pitch a follow-up project is immediately after wowing the client.
Beginners should start with platform sales due to low barrier to entry.
Cold email is harder to get right but offers higher upside than platform sales.
Client relationships built in communities can grow far beyond initial expectations.
key_datapoints: Cold email campaigns have generated millions of dollars in revenue.
One client closed $15,000 in a single month via LinkedIn outreach.
Sales calls typically last 30 to 45 minutes.
A $19,000 project can pay for itself in the first month based on saved $50,000 in pain.
The speaker has taught this sales framework to over 6,000 people.
Clients can expect a daily update Monday through Friday.
The kickoff call lasts about 30 minutes.
A Loom video walkthrough takes just a few minutes to record after project completion.
The Gumroad library includes builds sold for $2,000 to $15,000.
The speakers agencies reached $160,000 per month in combined revenue.
The goal is to reach $25,000 per month or beyond in revenue.
The 90-day customer guarantee promises a paying customer or money back.
The speaker has personally used these systems to scale to $160,000/month.
